Other complications of IgAV include small bowel infarction and perforation, and, in the case of renal involvement, IgA nephritis, which in severe cases may progress to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. In most cases, however, IgAV is uncomplicated and self-limited, and supportive therapy and monitoring for complications are a sufficient initial treatment approach in patients like this one.

B) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency can develop from adrenal hemorrhage as a complication of infection with endotoxin-producing bacteria such as N. meningitidis (i.e., Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome). Meningococcal meningitis can manifest with a purpuric rash over the lower extremities, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of meningococcal meningitis such as fever, headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. IgAV is not associated with adrenal insufficiency.
Image Description:

There are multiple small, nonblanching purple macules on the upper thigh, medial aspect of the knee, and anterior lower leg.

This appearance is consistent with purpura due to Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Thrombocytopenia in a child who recently had an infection and now presents with a purpuric rash is indicative of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). ITP is typically associated with viral infections, whereas this patient most likely had a bacterial infection, for which he was treated with an antibiotic. Furthermore, ITP does not manifest with arthralgia. IgAV is associated with a normal or increased rather than a decreased platelet count.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) can develop from acute rheumatic fever (ARF), a complication of infection with Group A streptococci (e.g., pharyngitis). ARF can manifest with arthralgia and a rash 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis. However, skin findings in ARF usually also involve the trunk and show a pink or light-red rash with a well-defined outer border and central clearing (erythema marginatum), unlike what is seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient received prompt treatment with penicillin for his pharyngitis, so manifestations of ARF (including MR) are unlikely. IgAV is not associated with MR.
Image Description:

Left upper arm of a child diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever (ARF)

Erythematous plaques with areas of central clearing are visible on the ventral aspect of the forearm.

This is characteristic of erythema marginatum, the characteristic annular erythema occuring in 10% of attacks of acute rheumatic fever in children, caused by group A streptococcus.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior uveitis can develop as a complication of systemic immune-mediated conditions. In a patient < 16 years of age with concomitant arthralgia in two weight-bearing joints (i.e., the knees), anterior uveitis should raise concern for juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), specifically for the subtype oligoarticular JIA. However, this condition does not manifest with a rash, and arthralgia would have to be present for > 6 weeks to establish the diagnosis. This patient has IgAV, another systemic immune-mediated condition, which is not associated with anterior uveitis.
questions.hint: The photograph shows a symmetric, coalescent, erythematous rash over both legs. In a child with arthralgia, mild gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea), and a history of an upper respiratory tract infection, this indicates IgA vasculitis (IgAV).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man reports painful lesions on his lower legs for the past 2 months. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and continues to drink six beers daily. He acknowledges using marijuana and cocaine. He denies fevers, chills, cough, sinus congestion, dyspnea, abdominal symptoms, joint pain, or focal weakness.
His vital signs are within normal limits, and he appears comfortable. His heart, lung, and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Distal pulses are intact. His lower extremities have multiple, small, erythematous macules that are palpable, tender, and nonblanching. Similar small lesions are present on his earlobes.
Laboratory evaluation reveals normal comprehensive metabolic panel, kidney function tests, liver function tests, and urinalysis. Additional laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
3700
4500–11,000


Neutrophils (%)
71
40–70


Lymphocytes (%)
22
22–44


Monocytes (%)
5
4–11


Eosinophils (%)
2
0–8


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hr)
27
0–17


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
13.00
0.08–3.10


Antibody to myeloperoxidase (U/mL)
354
<1.4


Antibody to proteinase 3 (U/mL)
32
<2.8


Complement C3 (mg/dL)
150
86–184


Complement C4 (mg/dL)
32
20–58


His antinuclear antibody, rheumatoid factor, cryoglobulin, and antiphospholipid antibody tests were negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Much of the cocaine in the United States is cut with the contaminant levamisole, a veterinary anthelmintic drug. Inhaled levamisole in cocaine has been associated with a syndrome of cutaneous vasculitis, arthralgias, and systemic symptoms, often associated with high titers of antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) in unusual patterns, such as positivity for both myeloperoxidase and proteinase 3 antigens — or discordance between the pattern of immunofluorescence ANCA staining and autoantibody specificity. Involvement of the non-cartilaginous part of the earlobe is common with cocaine-associated vasculitis, but it is rare in other vasculitides. Treatment is largely supportive; avoiding contaminated cocaine is key.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of cutaneous vasculitis in a patient who uses recreational drugs is cocaine that is contaminated with levamisole.

B) INCORRECT:

The antiphospholipid syndrome is characterized by recurrent arterial or venous thrombosis. It can manifest with cutaneous infarcts but is not associated with a positive test for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis C-induced vasculitis is almost always associated with cryoglobulinemia and usually with hypocomplementemia. This type of vasculitis is not associated with antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies.

D) INCORRECT:

About 50% of patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss syndrome) have a positive antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies test (usually specific for myeloperoxidase); however, this patient’s lack of asthma or peripheral eosinophilia makes this condition much less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa is not associated with antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies to proteinase 3, or myeloperoxidase.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with several days of joint pain in her knees and ankles, as well as a fleeting rash on her lower extremities. She also reports a 2-week history of abdominal pain, intermittent bloody stools, and nausea, leading to decreased oral intake. She has had no recent infections, sinus disease, or asthma.
On examination, she appears moderately ill. Her temperature is 37.7°C, her blood pressure is 122/90 mm Hg, her pulse is 96 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. She has scattered, palpable purpuric lesions on her lower extremities. Her cardiac and pulmonary examinations are normal. Her abdomen is soft, with mild tenderness in the periumbilical area and lower quadrants bilaterally. Both of her knees are swollen and tender. The remainder of her joint examination is unremarkable. She has no focal neurological deficits.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.0
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
504,000
150,000–350,000


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hr)
98
1–25


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
12
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.7
0.6–1.1


Her leukocyte count is 18,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), with a normal differential. She has normal C3 and C4 complement and a negative antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody test. Urinalysis shows 2+ blood, no proteinuria, and no white cells.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss syndrome) almost always features asthma and elevated circulating eosinophil levels. Sinusitis, neuropathy purpura or nodular skin lesions, and eosinophilic inflammation of the lungs are common, and the heart, gastrointestinal tract, brain, or kidney may become involved. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies may be seen in half of patients with EGPA.

B) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a vasculitis of small to medium-sized arteries. Symptoms result from ischemia of affected organs. The skin lesions reflect inflammation in larger and deeper arteries than those that cause palpable purpura, leading to nodules, ulcers, and/or livedo racemosa. The other most common manifestations of PAN are fever, weight loss, joint and muscle pains, neuropathy, kidney failure, intestinal angina, and, in men, testicular pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemia (the presence of circulating immunoglobulins that become insoluble at lower temperatures) is associated with plasma-cell dyscrasias (such as multiple myeloma and Waldenström macroglobulinemia), hepatitis C virus infection, and a variety of autoimmune diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus and rheumatoid arthritis. Complement depletion (particularly low C4) occurs in at least 80% of cases. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis most commonly causes a purpuric rash, arthralgia, and neuropathy, but membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is also common, and a wide range of internal organs can be involved.

D) CORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is a small-vessel vasculitis characterized by purpura, arthritis, abdominal pain, and hematuria. It is much more common in children than adults, but it is also an important component of the differential diagnosis of vasculitis in adulthood.

IgA vasculitis most typically manifests with rash (generally involving the lower extremities), subcutaneous edema, abdominal pain, joint pain (arthritis or arthralgia commonly affecting the hips, knees, or ankles), bloody stools, and, in men, scrotal edema. Approximately half of patients with IgA vasculitis have a preceding upper respiratory tract infection.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a young woman with abdominal pain, palpable purpura, and arthritis is IgA vasculitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis features a positive test for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies in the great majority of cases, usually with specificity for myeloperoxidase. Arthralgia, myalgia, purpura, neuropathy, glomerulonephritis (often severe), and pulmonary vasculitis leading to hemorrhage are all common manifestations.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a rash that started 2 weeks ago at the tops of her shins and has since spread to her feet. She reports associated pruritus and burning but no other symptoms, including fevers, chills, headaches, paresthesias, motor weakness, photosensitivity, alopecia, dry eyes or dry mouth, bloody nasal discharge, dyspnea, hemoptysis, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthritis, arthralgias, or Raynaud phenomenon. She takes no medications.
Physical examination confirms the presence of rash on both shins (figure) with no erosions, ulcerations, or nodules.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a normal comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, urinalysis, and complement levels, as well as negative testing for antinuclear antibody, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, antiphospholipid antibody, anti-citrullinated protein antibody, hypercoagulation panel, cryoglobulins, and rheumatoid factor.
A skin biopsy shows leukocytoclastic vasculitis.
What is the most appropriate first-line therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Palpable purpura extending over the shins and tops of the feet is most consistent with a small-vessel vasculitis of the skin. Although Sweet syndrome, nonvasculitic hypersensitivity reactions, and vasculopathy due to a hypercoagulable state can also manifest with palpable purpura, these conditions tend to have other distinctive features as well, which are not present in this case. Skin biopsy may be performed to confirm the presence of small-vessel vasculitis. In this case, the biopsy revealed leukocytoclastic vasculitis (LCV), a pathologic diagnosis that describes the histologic features of small-vessel vasculitis.

When LCV is present on skin biopsy, the differential diagnosis for causative disease states is broad and includes:

• Drug hypersensitivity reactions
• Acute or chronic infections
• Systemic vasculitides
• Connective tissue diseases
• Malignancy

Hence, a broad laboratory workup is appropriate in select cases. However, no etiology is identified in approximately 30% to 70% of cases.

This patient has no other systemic signs of a connective tissue disease or vasculitis, and her workup is negative, with no new medications or recent infections as a trigger for her symptoms. Symptomatic management, including topical glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, leg elevation, analgesics, and/or antihistamines, may therefore be sufficient. If the patient develops cutaneous necrosis or ulcerations, additional treatment is warranted.

For those with LCV who require treatment because of disease severity or chronicity, multiple medications may be effective, including systemic glucocorticoids, colchicine, dapsone, and azathioprine.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment for idiopathic cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis is symptomatic management.

B) INCORRECT:

Palpable purpura extending over the shins and tops of the feet is most consistent with a small-vessel vasculitis of the skin. Symptomatic management, including topical glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, leg elevation, analgesics, and/or antihistamines, may therefore be sufficient. If the patient develops cutaneous necrosis or ulcerations, additional treatment is warranted.

For those with leukocytoclastic vasculitis who require treatment because of disease severity or chronicity, multiple medications may be effective, including systemic glucocorticoids, colchicine, dapsone, and azathioprine.

C) INCORRECT:

Palpable purpura extending over the shins and tops of the feet is most consistent with a small-vessel vasculitis of the skin. Symptomatic management, including topical glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, leg elevation, analgesics, and/or antihistamines, may therefore be sufficient. If the patient develops cutaneous necrosis or ulcerations, additional treatment is warranted.

For those with leukocytoclastic vasculitis who require treatment because of disease severity or chronicity, multiple medications may be effective, including systemic glucocorticoids, colchicine, dapsone, and azathioprine.

D) INCORRECT:

Palpable purpura extending over the shins and tops of the feet is most consistent with a small-vessel vasculitis of the skin. Symptomatic management, including topical glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, leg elevation, analgesics, and/or antihistamines, may therefore be sufficient. If the patient develops cutaneous necrosis or ulcerations, additional treatment is warranted.

For those with leukocytoclastic vasculitis who require treatment because of disease severity or chronicity, multiple medications may be effective, including systemic glucocorticoids, colchicine, dapsone, and azathioprine.

E) INCORRECT:

Palpable purpura extending over the shins and tops of the feet is most consistent with a small-vessel vasculitis of the skin. Symptomatic management, including topical glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, leg elevation, analgesics, and/or antihistamines, may therefore be sufficient. If the patient develops cutaneous necrosis or ulcerations, additional treatment is warranted.

For those with leukocytoclastic vasculitis who require treatment because of disease severity or chronicity, multiple medications may be effective, including systemic glucocorticoids, colchicine, dapsone, and azathioprine.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-day history of a painful rash over his legs. He has not had fevers, joint pain, shortness of breath, cough, chest pain, or abdominal pain. Two weeks ago, he was admitted to the hospital for community-acquired pneumonia and was treated with ceftriaxone and azithromycin. His medical history is remarkable for hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender, nonblanching palpable purpura over his lower legs. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,200/mm3



Neutrophils
68%


Lymphocytes
23%


Eosinophils
2%


Platelet count
250,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

135 mEq/L


K+

3.7 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
10 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (c-ANCA)
Negative


Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA)
Negative


Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis (CSVV), i.e., hypersensitivity vasculitis, is a non-ANCA-associated necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels caused by immune complex deposition that is limited to the skin, with no involvement of other organs. This condition can be idiopathic or triggered by certain drugs (e.g., cephalosporins, sulfasalazine), infections (e.g., HIV, HCV), or autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE). Diagnosis requires ruling out systemic vasculitis. A skin biopsy typically revealing leukocytoclastic vasculitis is needed to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment involves management of the underlying cause (e.g., discontinuation of causative drugs). Immunosuppressive therapy may be required depending on disease severity and chronicity.

B) INCORRECT:

IgA vasculitis is a type of non-ANCA-associated small-vessel vasculitis that manifests with symmetrical palpable purpura on the lower extremities. Factors contributing to the development of this condition include preceding infections and certain drugs, such as macrolides. However, IgA vasculitis mostly occurs in children and typically manifests with arthralgia, gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., colicky abdominal pain), and kidney involvement (e.g., hematuria, proteinuria), which are not seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis is a type of non-ANCA-associated small-vessel vasculitis that manifests with palpable purpura. This condition is most commonly caused by cryoglobulinemia due to hepatitis C infection and typically involves other organs, resulting in systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, arthralgia, myalgia), glomerulonephritis, and/or polyneuropathy. This patient's condition is limited to the skin, making an alternative diagnosis is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis that may manifest with purpura of the lower extremities and lower respiratory tract involvement. However, patients with GPA typically present with constitutional and ENT symptoms (e.g., chronic rhinitis, chronic otitis), renal involvement (e.g., elevated creatinine, hematuria), and ocular, and/or cardiac involvement. Moreover, laboratory studies in GPA show increased inflammatory markers and positive c-ANCA.

E) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis that may manifest with palpable purpura. Patients with EGPA typically present with asthma attacks, tender nodules, mononeuritis multiplex, and gastrointestinal, cardiac (e.g., pericarditis), and/or renal involvement (e.g., elevated BUN and creatinine). Constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, fever) are also common in EGPA. Moreover, blood tests typically show eosinophilia and are often positive for p-ANCA.
questions.hint: This patient presents with tender, symmetrical palpable purpura on the lower extremities that manifested several days after cephalosporin administration. He has no systemic symptoms or abnormal laboratory results, which suggests a specific type of small-vessel vasculitis.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of progressively worsening joint pain. She describes diffuse, aching pain in her knees, shoulders, and hands bilaterally, which has become much more severe over the past few weeks. She also reports night sweats and generalized malaise. On examination, her radial pulses are weak. There are erythematous nodules measuring 3–5 cm over her legs. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit (Hct), blood
0.332 L/L (0.38–0.50)


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
107 g/L (115–155)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
11.3 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
615 × 109/L (130–380)


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), blood

94 mm/h (0–20)


C-reactive protein, blood
400 mg/L (≤ 10)


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis (GCT) is more common in women and can cause malaise, arthralgias, night sweats, decreased peripheral pulses, an elevated ESR, increased CRP, anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis. However, GCT is almost exclusively seen in patients above the age of 50 years, and cutaneous manifestations are not seen. Instead, patients typically have a history of headache, scalp pain, and jaw claudication because the temporal artery is frequently affected.

B) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) can manifest with erythematous nodules, malaise, night sweats, arthralgia, anemia, leukocytosis, and elevated ESR and CRP. However, decreased radial pulsations are typically not present because peripheral vascular disease is a rare manifestation of PAN. Instead, patients usually present with hypertension and/or renal insufficiency (due to renal artery stenosis) and symptoms of neuropathy (e.g., paresthesias, sensory loss, weakness).

C) CORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous inflammation involving all layers of the walls of large arteries such as the aorta and its major branches. Its incidence peaks at 15–45 years of age and it is more common in women (especially those of Asian ethnicity). In the initial stages of the disease, patients have nonspecific symptoms such as fever, malaise, and/or arthralgia. Eventually, the large arteries narrow, which causes decreased peripheral pulses (so-called pulseless disease). Systemic inflammation causes elevation of ESR, CRP, leukocyte count, and thrombocyte count. In some patients, necrotizing inflammation of medium-sized subcutaneous vessels occurs, which results in erythema nodosum.

See “Overview of large-vessel vasculitides” table.

Key learning point: Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis in young women, presenting with systemic symptoms, diminished pulses, elevated inflammatory markers, and sometimes erythema nodosum.
Image Description:

MRI angiography aorta (A: with contrast; sagittal plane. B: inversion recovery dark blood sequence; axial plane)

The descending aorta shows luminal dilatation and irregularity (A: green overlay), with multiple areas of wall thickening (B: examples indicated by red dimension lines).

These features are characteristic of Takayasu arteritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Because thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO) causes endarteritis and occlusion of distal, medium-sized arteries, it could manifest in a young adult with decreased radial pulses. However, TAO is much more common in men, and features such as malaise, night sweats, arthralgia, erythematous nodules, a raised ESR, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis would not be expected. Instead, a history of smoking, Raynaud phenomenon, and features of superficial thrombophlebitis (cord-like, painful veins) would be present.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis can cause malaise, arthralgias, night sweats, skin nodules, anemia, leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, and an elevated ESR and CRP. However, microscopic polyangiitis is usually seen in middle-aged adults. Furthermore, decreased peripheral pulses would not be expected because microscopic polyangiitis predominantly involves small arteries (arterioles). Instead, patients present with features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hematuria, hypertension) and acute renal failure (e.g., oliguria) as a result of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, or hemoptysis due to alveolar hemorrhage.
questions.hint: Aortic arteriography of this patient would show areas of thickening and narrowing of the aortic arch.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of recurrent episodes of chest pain and palpitations over the past two months. During this time, he has experienced a 4-kg weight loss, malaise, bilateral knee pain, and diffuse myalgias. He was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection five years ago and has been taking tenofovir since then. His temperature is 38°C, pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal except for tachycardia. There are several ulcerations around both ankles and calves. Laboratory studies show the following:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
110 g/L (125–170)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
14.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), blood
80 mm/h (0–10)


Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies
Negative


Hepatitis B surface antigen
Positive


Protein, urine
+2


RBC, urine
6–7/hpf


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by progressive inflammation and thrombosis that results in claudication with absent peripheral pulses and cold extremities. It may cause ulcerations of the distal extremities and muscle pain. However, findings would usually include migratory thrombophlebitis and Raynaud's phenomenon, as well as normal ESR levels. Thromboangiitis obliterans would also not explain the involvement of multiple organ systems.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener's granulomatosis) can manifest with malaise, arthralgias, skin lesions, as well as renal and cardiac symptoms and increased ESR. However, the absence of upper respiratory tract disease (e.g., sinusitis, otitis media) and ocular involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, diplopia) suggests a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Churg-Strauss syndrome is a type of small vessel vasculitis that may present with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms. However, patients with Churg-Strauss syndrome often have a history of recurrent asthma attacks and positive testing for pANCA.

D) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that often manifests with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms. However, patients with microscopic polyangiitis commonly have pulmonary symptoms (e.g., hemoptysis). Furthermore, individuals with microscopic polyangiitis are pANCA positive in ∼ 70% of cases.

E) CORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), like most vasculitides, usually involves multiple organ systems, as seen in this patient (skin, kidneys, heart). The absence of pANCA and pulmonary symptoms, as well as the association with hepatitis B (and hepatitis C), helps to differentiate PAN from other forms of vasculitis. Muscle biopsy of this patient would most likely show transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

PAN should be always considered in young adults presenting with stroke or myocardial infarction.

Key learning point: Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium-vessel vasculitis associated with hepatitis B, presenting with multisystem involvement, skin ulcers, renal findings, and negative ANCA serology.
questions.hint: This patient presents with nonspecific symptoms (fever, arthralgia, malaise, weight loss), cutaneous symptoms (ulcerations), cardiac symptoms (chest pain, palpitations), and renal manifestations (proteinuria, hematuria), as well as elevated ESR and leukocytosis, all of which are findings consistent with a multisystemic vasculitis. A negative pANCA and a history of a hepatitis B infection indicate a certain subtype of vasculitis that usually spares the lungs.

questions.text: You are seeing an 8-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic with a 6-day history of knee pain, mild nausea, and a nonpruritic rash on his legs. Two weeks ago, he had a sore throat and mild fever, which was treated with penicillin. His medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any routine medications. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 95/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is provided. Serum creatinine is 71 μmol/L (49–93). Urinalysis is normal. This patient is at increased risk for which one of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) can develop from acute rheumatic fever (ARF), a complication of infection with Group A streptococci (e.g., pharyngitis). ARF can manifest with arthralgia and a rash 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis. However, skin findings in ARF usually also involve the trunk and show a pink or light-red rash with a well-defined outer border and central clearing (erythema marginatum), unlike what is seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient received prompt treatment with penicillin for his pharyngitis, so manifestations of ARF (including MR) are unlikely. IgAV is not associated with MR.

B) CORRECT:

IgAV develops as a result of immune complex deposition in the vascular walls, which causes small vessel vasculitis, submucosal hemorrhage, and edema in the gastrointestinal tract. The thickened bowel wall can form a pathologic lead point for intussusception, which in IgAV is typically ileoileal and limited to the small bowel. Other complications of IgAV include small bowel infarction and perforation, and, in the case of renal involvement, IgA nephritis, which in severe cases may progress to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. In most cases, however, IgAV is uncomplicated and self-limited, and supportive therapy and monitoring for complications are a sufficient initial treatment approach in patients like this one.

Key learning point: IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) increases the risk of intussusception due to bowel wall edema and submucosal hemorrhage from small vessel vasculitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterior uveitis can develop as a complication of systemic immune-mediated conditions. In a patient < 16 years of age with concomitant arthralgia in two weight-bearing joints (i.e., the knees), anterior uveitis should raise concern for juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), specifically for the subtype oligoarticular JIA. However, this condition does not manifest with a rash, and arthralgia would have to be present for > 6 weeks to establish the diagnosis. This patient has IgAV, another systemic immune-mediated condition, which is not associated with anterior uveitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombocytopenia in a child who recently had an infection and now presents with a purpuric rash is indicative of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). ITP is typically associated with viral infections, whereas this patient most likely had a bacterial infection, for which he was treated with an antibiotic. Furthermore, ITP does not manifest with arthralgia. IgAV is associated with a normal or increased rather than a decreased platelet count.

E) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency can develop from adrenal hemorrhage as a complication of infection with endotoxin-producing bacteria such as N. meningitidis (i.e., Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome). Meningococcal meningitis can manifest with a purpuric rash over the lower extremities, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of meningococcal meningitis such as fever, headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. IgAV is not associated with adrenal insufficiency.
questions.hint: The photograph shows a symmetric, coalescent, erythematous rash over both legs. In a child with arthralgia, mild gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea), and a history of an upper respiratory tract infection, this indicates IgA vasculitis (IgAV).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of diffuse muscle pain, malaise, bilateral knee pain, and recurrent episodes of abdominal and chest pain. He reports a 5-kg weight loss over the past 4 months. He was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection 4 years ago and has been taking tenofovir since then. On examination, there are several ulcerations around both ankles and calves. Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are negative. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria and hematuria. Muscle biopsy shows transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that often manifests with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms, as well as fibrinoid necrosis, as seen here. However, patients with microscopic polyangiitis commonly have pulmonary symptoms, (e.g., hemoptysis). Furthermore, individuals with microscopic polyangiitis are p-ANCA positive in ∼ 70% of cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by progressive inflammation and thrombosis that results in claudication with absent peripheral pulses and cold extremities. It may cause ulcerations of the distal extremities and muscle pain, as seen in this patient. However, findings would usually include migratory thrombophlebitis and Raynaud's phenomenon. Thromboangiitis obliterans would also not explain the involvement of multiple organ systems, and the biopsy findings in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that can manifest with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms, as seen here. However, patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis often have a history of recurrent asthma attacks and positive testing for p-ANCA. Furthermore, biopsy typically reveals tissue eosinophilia with granulomatous reactions.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis can manifest with malaise, arthralgias, skin lesions, as well as renal and cardiac symptoms, as seen in this patient. However, the absence of upper respiratory tract disease (e.g., sinusitis, otitis media) and ocular involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, diplopia) suggests a different diagnosis. Furthermore, biopsy typically shows necrotic, partially granulomatous vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels.

E) CORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) like most vasculitides, usually involves multiple organ systems, as seen in this patient (skin, kidneys, heart). The absence of p-ANCA and pulmonary symptoms, as well as the association with Hepatitis B (and C), helps to differentiate PAN from other forms of vasculitis. Muscle biopsy typically shows transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis, as seen in this patient. Other typical characteristics of PAN include a high ESR level, proteinuria, and hematuria. PAN should be always considered in young adults presenting with stroke or myocardial infarction.

Key learning point: Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium-vessel vasculitis associated with hepatitis B, characterized by multisystem involvement, negative ANCA, and transmural arterial inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with several nonspecific symptoms (arthralgia, malaise, weight loss), cutaneous symptoms (several ulcerations), cardiac symptoms (chest pain), gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain), and renal symptoms (proteinuria, hematuria) is consistent with a multisystemic vasculitis. His negative p-ANCA, hepatitis B infection, and biopsy findings indicate a certain subtype of vasculitis that usually spares the lungs.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of injection drug use presents with a 2-week history of fever, abdominal pain, and weakness in his right foot. Physical examination reveals livedo reticularis on his lower extremities, a tender nodule on his calf, and diminished sensation in his right lower extremity with foot drop. He reports no recent medication changes and denies current drug use, though he used heroin "on and off" over the past year. Which of the following is the most valuable diagnostic step?

choices.text: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein
Hepatitis B surface antigen and hepatitis C antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While ESR and CRP would likely be elevated and could support the presence of systemic inflammation, they are nonspecific and would not identify the most likely underlying etiology in this high-risk patient.

B) INCORRECT:

ANCA testing is used to evaluate for ANCA-associated small-vessel vasculitides such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis or microscopic polyangiitis. However, this patient's presentation (livedo reticularis, subcutaneous nodules, mononeuritis multiplex, abdominal pain) is more consistent with medium-vessel vasculitis, specifically polyarteritis nodosa, which is typically ANCA-negative. Given this patient's injection drug use history, secondary causes should be ruled out first.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with features of medium-vessel vasculitis, including livedo reticularis, subcutaneous nodules, and mononeuritis multiplex (foot drop) in the setting of injection drug use. Hepatitis B and C are well-established causes of secondary vasculitides, particularly polyarteritis nodosa, and are common among injection drug users. Testing for these infectious causes is the most appropriate initial step before pursuing other vasculitis workup.

D) INCORRECT:

Temporal artery biopsy would be appropriate for suspected giant cell arteritis, but this patient's age, presentation, and risk factors do not suggest large-vessel vasculitis. The combination of abdominal pain, livedo reticularis, and mononeuritis multiplex is more consistent with medium-vessel disease.

E) INCORRECT:

While nerve conduction studies could confirm the mononeuropathy, they would not address the underlying systemic vasculitic process. Identifying and treating an infectious etiology is the priority given this patient's risk factors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of fever, arthralgias, and a rash on her lower extremities. Physical examination reveals palpable purpuric lesions on both legs that do not blanch with pressure. Her medical history is significant for hypertension, and she reports that several of her blood pressure medications were adjusted 4 weeks ago due to inadequate control, with one new agent being added to her regimen. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for her current presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with drug-induced vasculitis, evidenced by the development of constitutional symptoms and palpable purpura approximately 4 weeks after medication changes. Lisinopril and other ACE inhibitors are not commonly associated with drug-induced vasculitis and are more typically associated with angioedema and hyperkalemia.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with drug-induced vasculitis, evidenced by the development of constitutional symptoms and palpable purpura approximately 4 weeks after medication changes. Metoprolol and other beta-blockers are not commonly associated with drug-induced vasculitis and their main adverse effects include bradycardia and bronchospasm.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with drug-induced vasculitis, evidenced by the development of constitutional symptoms and palpable purpura approximately 4 weeks after medication changes. Amlodipine and other calcium channel blockers are not typically associated with drug-induced vasculitis and more commonly cause peripheral edema and gingival hyperplasia.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with drug-induced vasculitis, evidenced by the development of constitutional symptoms and palpable purpura approximately 4 weeks after medication changes. Hydralazine is one of the most well-recognized medications associated with drug-induced vasculitis and is commonly added as additional therapy for resistant hypertension, making it the most likely culprit among the listed options.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with drug-induced vasculitis, evidenced by the development of constitutional symptoms and palpable purpura approximately 4 weeks after medication changes. Hydrochlorothiazide and other thiazide diuretics are not commonly associated with drug-induced vasculitis and are more likely to cause electrolyte abnormalities and hyperuricemia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with a 6-week history of chronic nasal congestion with bloody discharge, persistent cough with hemoptysis, and fatigue. He reports a 15-pound unintentional weight loss and dark urine over the past 2 weeks. Physical examination reveals nasal septal perforation, bilateral pulmonary crackles, and palpable purpura on his lower extremities. Laboratory studies show serum creatinine of 2.8 mg/dL and urinalysis with proteinuria, hematuria, and red blood cell casts. Chest imaging reveals multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules, some with cavitation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While giant cell arteritis should be considered in patients ≥ 50 years of age, this patient's presentation is inconsistent with GCA. Giant cell arteritis typically presents with temporal headache, jaw claudication, and visual symptoms due to involvement of large vessels (particularly branches of the carotid arteries). The combination of upper respiratory tract involvement with nasal septal perforation, cavitary pulmonary lesions, and glomerulonephritis is not characteristic of giant cell arteritis, which rarely involves the kidneys or causes erosive nasal disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis can cause similar pulmonary-renal syndrome but characteristically spares the upper respiratory tract. This patient's nasal septal perforation and chronic sinusitis with bloody discharge are classic features of granulomatosis with polyangiitis, not microscopic polyangiitis.

C) INCORRECT:

IgA vasculitis predominantly affects children and typically presents with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and arthritis following upper respiratory infections. The severe upper and lower respiratory involvement with cavitary lung lesions is not characteristic of IgA vasculitis.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with the classic triad of granulomatosis with polyangiitis: upper respiratory tract involvement (chronic sinusitis with nasal septal perforation), lower respiratory tract involvement (cough, hemoptysis, cavitary pulmonary nodules), and glomerulonephritis (acute kidney injury with RBC casts). The combination of these three organ systems is pathognomonic for granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis typically presents with palpable purpura, arthralgia, and glomerulonephritis, often associated with hepatitis C infection. The extensive upper respiratory involvement with nasal septal perforation and cavitary lung lesions are not features of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of diffuse muscle pain, malaise, pain in both knees, recurrent episodes of abdominal and chest pain. He has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. Four years ago, he was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection and was started on tenofovir. There are several ulcerations around the ankle and calves bilaterally. Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are negative. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Muscle biopsy shows a transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis typically manifests with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), as seen here. However, this patient lacks important findings of GCA (e.g., pulse-synchronous throbbing, dull headache, temporal tenderness, and jaw claudication). Although GCA is also often associated with polymyalgia rheumatica that typically manifests with proximal muscle pain (shoulder, pelvic girdle) and stiffness, this patient has diffuse muscle and knee pain. Lastly, GCA is most common in women over 50 years of age, and unlike the biopsy findings in this patient, temporal artery biopsy typically shows granulomatous panarteritis, mononuclear cell infiltrates, and giant cell formation within the vessel wall.

B) CORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), like most vasculitides, usually involves multiple organ systems, as seen in this patient (skin, kidneys, heart). The absence of p-ANCA and pulmonary symptoms, as well as the association with Hepatitis B (and C), helps to differentiate PAN from other forms of vasculitis. Muscle biopsy typically shows transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis, as seen in this patient. Other typical characteristics of PAN include a high ESR level, proteinuria, and hematuria. PAN should always be considered in young adults presenting with stroke or myocardial infarction.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis can manifest with malaise, arthralgias, skin lesions, as well as renal and cardiac symptoms, as seen in this patient. However, the absence of upper respiratory tract disease (e.g., sinusitis, otitis media) and ocular involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, diplopia) suggests a different diagnosis. Furthermore, biopsy typically shows necrotic, partially granulomatous vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels.

D) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by progressive inflammation and thrombosis that results in claudication with absent peripheral pulses and cold extremities. It may cause ulcerations of the distal extremities and muscle pain, as seen in this patient. However, findings would usually include migratory thrombophlebitis and Raynaud's phenomenon. Thromboangiitis obliterans would also not explain the involvement of multiple organ systems, and the biopsy findings in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that can manifest with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms, as seen here. However, patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis often have a history of recurrent asthma attacks and positive testing for p-ANCA. Furthermore, biopsy typically reveals tissue eosinophilia with granulomatous reactions.

F) INCORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis often manifests with fever, malaise, weight loss, arthralgia, muscular pain, and cardiac symptoms (angina pectoris), all of which are findings in this patient. It is also associated with chronic hepatitis B. However, Takayasu arteritis typically manifests with decreased bilateral brachial and radial pulses (“pulseless disease”). Moreover, it typically occurs in Asian females under the age of 40 years, and unlike the biopsy findings in this patient, Takayasu arteritis typically manifests with granulomatous thickening of the aortic arch.

G) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that often manifests with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms, as well as fibrinoid necrosis, as seen here. However, patients with microscopic polyangiitis commonly have pulmonary symptoms, (e.g., hemoptysis). Furthermore, individuals with microscopic polyangiitis are p-ANCA positive in ∼ 70% of cases.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with several nonspecific symptoms (arthralgia, malaise, weight loss), cutaneous symptoms (several ulcerations), cardiac symptoms (chest pain), gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain), and renal symptoms (proteinuria, hematuria) is consistent with a multisystemic vasculitis. His negative p-ANCA, hepatitis B infection, and biopsy findings indicate a certain subtype of vasculitis that usually spares the lungs.
